sentences.text:
the scons snapshots in debian testing and unstable don't track dependencies correctly
for my programs.
the scons release 0.97 (available from ubuntu) works fine for me ...
afair, the scons devs don't recommend packaging checkpoint releases ...

i would somehow 
have a better feeling, if debian wouldn't do so, but provide the latest release instead
of a development version ...
Versions of packages scons depends on:

ii  python                        2.4.4-6    An interactive high-level object-o
ii  python-central                0.5.15     register and build utility for Pyt
On Sun, Dec 16, 2007 at 12:26:15PM +0100, Tim Blechmann wrote:
Are you sure that you are using Debian?

> the scons snapshots in debian testing and unstable don't track dependencies correctly
> for my programs.
the scons release 0.97 (available from ubuntu) works fine for me ...
Please provide a sample SConscript demonstrating this problem.

The
information you have provided is really not adequate
> afair, the scons devs don't recommend packaging checkpoint releases ...

i would somehow 
> have a better feeling, if debian wouldn't do so, but provide the latest release instead
> of a development version ...
No released version of Debian includes a snapshot release of SCons;

if
you're using a development snapshot of Debian then you should expect
things like this.
> On Sun, Dec 16, 2007 at 12:26:15PM +0100, Tim Blechmann wrote:
> Are you sure that you are using Debian?

i was installing the ubuntu package, as it provided a debian package for
the 0.97 release

> > the scons snapshots in debian testing and unstable don't track dependencies correctly
> > for my programs.
the scons release 0.97 (available from ubuntu) works fine for me ...
> Please provide a sample SConscript demonstrating this problem.

The
> information you have provided is really not adequate
i don't want to go into debugging scons ...
if you want to do so ...

the
scons build system for my application can be found at:

when i changed a header file, scons didn't rebuild the targets,
including this header ...
> > afair, the scons devs don't recommend packaging checkpoint releases ...

i would somehow 
> > have a better feeling, if debian wouldn't do so, but provide the latest release instead
> > of a development version ...
> No released version of Debian includes a snapshot release of SCons;

if
> you're using a development snapshot of Debian then you should expect
> things like this.

> We do not recommend that downstream distributions (Debian, Fedora,
> etc.)

debian stable doesn't include a checkpoint release, but that doesn't
mean, that testing/unstable should provide development versions ...
afaict, that is what experimental is for ...

Most of the trouble in this world has been caused by folks who can't
mind their own business, because they have no business of their own to
mind, any more than a smallpox virus has.
On Sun, Dec 16, 2007 at 01:05:57PM +0100, Tim Blechmann wrote:

> when i changed a header file, scons didn't rebuild the targets,
> including this header ...

Please be more specific about which header file you have changed and
what change you have made in it.

Using your SConscript files and source
I find that SCons is succesfully picking up changes in header files.

> > We do not recommend that downstream distributions (Debian, Fedora,
> > etc.)

> debian stable doesn't include a checkpoint release, but that doesn't
> mean, that testing/unstable should provide development versions ...
> afaict, that is what experimental is for ...
Experimental is for known broken things which SCons snapshots aren't.

> > when i changed a header file, scons didn't rebuild the targets,
> > including this header ...

> Please be more specific about which header file you have changed and
> what change you have made in it.

Using your SConscript files and source
> I find that SCons is succesfully picking up changes in header files.

as i said, i am currently busy with other things, so i don't want to
start debugging scons ...

there were issues, when changing header files, which are included by
files, that are autogenerated by my scons build system ...

> > > We do not recommend that downstream distributions (Debian, Fedora,
> > > etc.)

> > debian stable doesn't include a checkpoint release, but that doesn't
> > mean, that testing/unstable should provide development versions ...
> > afaict, that is what experimental is for ...
> Experimental is for known broken things which SCons snapshots aren't.

i had several complains from people compiling my software about broken
scons -c and scons --help ...

all of them were using scons checkpoint
releases from debian testing/unstable ...
does any other distribution except debian package checkpoint releases?
afaict, neither ubuntu, gentoo or fedora do so ...

Avoid the world, it's just a lot of dust and drag and means nothing in
the end.
On Sun, Dec 16, 2007 at 03:09:34PM +0100, Tim Blechmann wrote:

> as i said, i am currently busy with other things, so i don't want to
> start debugging scons ...

> there were issues, when changing header files, which are included by
> files, that are autogenerated by my scons build system ...
I am not asking you to do any work on SCons.

I am asking you to provide
me with enough information to allow me to debug the problem.

So far I
have done several tests based on the extremely limited information which 
you have provided, none of which have shown any problem so I can't
really do anything.

If you would provide me with enough information to
allow me to see the problem occurring on my systems I would be able to
investigate the problem and hopefully do something to fix it.

I really do not understand your reluctance to provide me with this
information.
> does any other distribution except debian package checkpoint releases?
> afaict, neither ubuntu, gentoo or fedora do so ...

you'd have to look at the other distributions and ask the
people responsible for the SCons packages in them.

I do know that
Ubuntu has snapshots too (AFAICT they're going to put one in their next
release as well).

I do know that other packages in Debian have from time to time required
features and bug fixes only present in snapshot releases and that the
additional exposure generated by including snapshot releases in
development versions of Debian provides much greater testing coverage
for SCons, all of which feeds back into the quality of actual SCons
releases.
> I am not asking you to do any work on SCons.

I am asking you to provide
> me with enough information to allow me to debug the problem.

So far I
> have done several tests based on the extremely limited information which 
> you have provided, none of which have shown any problem so I can't
> really do anything.

If you would provide me with enough information to
> allow me to see the problem occurring on my systems I would be able to
> investigate the problem and hopefully do something to fix it.

> I really do not understand your reluctance to provide me with this
> information.
i was trying to debug nova, not scons ...
- check out nova from git, go to the threaded_dsp branch

- change the file source/kernel/ugen/dsp_thread.hpp ... add a new line
or anything that changes it's md5 sum

that should trigger a rebuild of the pch, most object files and
debug/py_nova.so ...
> > does any other distribution except debian package checkpoint releases?
> > afaict, neither ubuntu, gentoo or fedora do so ...

you'd have to look at the other distributions and ask the
> people responsible for the SCons packages in them.

I do know that
> Ubuntu has snapshots too (AFAICT they're going to put one in their next
> release as well).
There's no such entity as "most people".

You've got to pin it down to a specific
person doing a specific thing at a specific time and space.
On Sun, Dec 16, 2007 at 04:29:28PM +0100, Tim Blechmann wrote:
> i was trying to debug nova, not scons ...
> - check out nova from git, go to the threaded_dsp branch

> omit_frame_pointer=True libsamplerate=True debug/py_nova.so -j2
> - change the file source/kernel/ugen/dsp_thread.hpp ...

add a new line
> or anything that changes it's md5 sum

After fixing a build failure (patch sent separately) I've now
managed to reproduce the problem you are seeing.

Note that I can't actually complete a build due to other compilation
failures but I can see the problem with the bits of the build that do
complete.
> > > does any other distribution except debian package checkpoint releases?
> > > afaict, neither ubuntu, gentoo or fedora do so ...

you'd have to look at the other distributions and ask the
> > people responsible for the SCons packages in them.

I do know that
> > Ubuntu has snapshots too (AFAICT they're going to put one in their next
> > release as well).

That's the current release version of Ubuntu - hardy is using a
snapshot.

In any case, I'm not sure what you're trying to say by simply
providing these links.

These are different distributions with different
software in them and different release timescales.

Like I say, other
bits of Debian do need the more current versions from time to time and
since we're not planning on doing a release for over 6 months we may as
well get the testing done now rather than later.

Look at it this way: would you rather catch this bug in a development
snapshot or wait for a release?
On Sun, Dec 16, 2007 at 04:29:28PM +0100, Tim Blechmann wrote:
> i was trying to debug nova, not scons ...
> - check out nova from git, go to the threaded_dsp branch

> omit_frame_pointer=True libsamplerate=True debug/py_nova.so -j2
> - change the file source/kernel/ugen/dsp_thread.hpp ...

add a new line
> or anything that changes it's md5 sum
I see what's going on here now.

The problem arises only when using your
Combine() builder (which is why I wasn't able to reproduce before you
provided instructions).

What is happening is that the Combine() builder is writing full paths to
the files it includes into the generated C or C++ file.

This causes
SCons to ignore the dependency since it assumes that a fully qualified
path is a reference to a file not part of the project build and which
should therefore not be included in dependency generation (this is a
noticable preformance win for users including files on networked
drives).
You could avoid the problem for now by arranging for your Combine()

builder to use relative rather than absolute paths or by not using the
Combine() builder.

We believe that the bug you reported is fixed in the latest version of
scons, which is due to be installed in the Debian FTP archive:

A summary of the changes between this version and the previous one is
attached.
Thank you for reporting the bug, which will now be closed.

If you
have further comments please address them to 456518@bugs.debian.org,
and the maintainer will reopen the bug report if appropriate.
Mark Brown <broonie@debian.org> (supplier of updated scons package)
(This message was generated automatically at their request;

if you
believe that there is a problem with it please contact the archive
administrators by mailing ftpmaster@debian.org)

* Apply upstream patch fixing handling of absolute paths (closes: #456518).
